docs.lead_paragraph: The lot of Appalachia's coal miners has ever been a struggle, above ground and below. And now comes a fresh blow for more than 3,000 unionized miners who will lose their health care and retirement benefits under a federal judge's ruling that it is not necessary for their troubled employer to honor its contract guarantees. Some veteran miners among the 2,300 affected retirees already suffer from black lung and other occupational diseases, but they nevertheless face loss of their medical benefits. So do 1,000 active miners, under the order of a bankruptcy judge in Kentucky. The ruling makes it easier for Horizon Natural Resources, the nation's fourth-largest coal company, to sell its six unionized mines as it undergoes bankruptcy. Potential buyers prefer the company's nonunion mines as better bargains, since they are freer of ongoing financial obligations to workers. So the order canceling medical and other contract benefits presumably levels the auction field for buyers. This is small comfort for the miners caught in the crunch of federal bankruptcy law.

docs.lead_paragraph: What happened to Governor McGreevey that is, James E. McGreevey, the Democratic governor of New Jersey, who announced his resignation on Thursday because he was secretly gay and had ''shamefully'' conducted an extramarital affair -- was strange, to say the least. Pundits wondered whether there would be broader ramifications for gay civil rights, same-sex marriage or American politics. I doubt it. A rich and seemingly unique concatenation of homosexuality, adultery, suspicions of political featherbedding, and rumors of extortion and sexual harassment made the McGreevey scandal look like an aberration. What happened to Mr. McGreevey -- the man, not the governor -- was not strange at all. It was familiar to almost every gay American of Mr. McGreevey's generation. Marriage, not homosexuality, lies at the heart of it.

docs.lead_paragraph: To the Editor: Your article on Steve Brozak's challenge in New Jersey's Seventh Congressional District (''Ex-Marine Takes Aim at a Republican,'' Aug. 8) ignored health care issues, which can truly gauge a candidate's independence. The record of the incumbent, Mike Ferguson, on health care is not attractive, even to the district you describe as the wealthiest in the state. We have money and health insurance, but we also have a humane concern for the health of seniors and other citizens who are not as advantaged. These populations have not been well served by Mr. Ferguson's voting record. The American Public Health Association, a nonpartisan professional society, tracks votes in Congress on legislation of importance for health care. Mr. Ferguson scored zero percent on these issues for two consecutive years, the only member of the New Jersey delegation to get the zero score. Is this independence? This voting record matches that of Representative Tom Delay of Texas and is in lock step with the Bush agenda. Joseph d'Oronzio Summit The writer is an associate clinical professor of health policy and management at Columbia University.

docs.lead_paragraph: Westchester Medical Center has hemorrhaged millions of dollars since spinning free of county control in 1998: $32 million this year and $43 million last year. An outside management firm has been working to stabilize things while a cluster of worried public officials, including County Executive Andrew Spano and William Ryan, chairman of the Board of Legislators, pace the waiting room and keep a wary eye on the county's bond rating. (The hospital is independent, but the county backs its debt.) The hospital's Long Island counterpart, the Nassau Health Care Corporation, is also in horrible shape. It is poised to run out of money by the end of the year. A state audit last week portrayed an institution overcome by debt and dysfunction while its president ran amok, giving himself and others hundreds of thousands of dollars in unauthorized raises and accepting gifts from contractors in violation of state ethics laws.

Horowitz of Merrick, N.Y., was married last evening to Jacob Mark Zlotoff, a son of Rebecca and Lee David Zlotoff of Santa Monica, Calif. Rabbi Rav A. Soloff, a grandfather of the bridegroom, officiated at the Woodbury Country Club in Woodbury, N.Y., with Rabbi Jeffrey A. Marx taking part in the ceremony. Mrs. Zlotoff, 27, is a senior social worker at Partnership With Children in Manhattan, which counsels and provides social services to disadvantaged children in New York City's public schools. In September, she is to become its supervisor at Public School 256 in Brooklyn. She graduated from the State University of New York at Binghamton and received a master's degree in social work from the University of Pennsylvania and a certificate in Jewish education from Gratz College in Philadelphia.
